entry.title: PGP Key Transition Statement
entry.summary:
I am moving to a new OpenPGP key pair so I am publishing the below transition to statement. I have been wanting to move to a new 4096-bit key for some time now, but decided it was time to make the move after recently receiving a Keybase invite from the creator of Sendto. More details about the transition are in the signed statement below. If you have any questions, please let me know.

By the way, feel free to use my transition statement as a template for your own. Mine was based off of Simon Josefsson’s, whose version was derived from earlier examples as detailed in his Offline GnuPG Master Key and Subkeys on YubiKey NEO Smartcard article.

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA512

OpenPGP Key Transition Statement for Matthew Vance

I created a new OpenPGP key and am transitioning away from
my old key. The old key has not been compromised and will continue to
be valid for some time, but I prefer all future correspondence to be
encrypted to the new key. I also plan to make signatures with the new
key going forward.

I would like this new key to be re-integrated into the web of trust.
This message is signed by both keys to certify the transition. My new
and old keys are signed by each other. If you have signed my old key,
I would appreciate signatures on my new key as well, provided that
your signing policy permits this without re-authenticating me.

The old key is:
pub   2048R/0xB55BD4DD57A773EA 2010-05-07
      Key fingerprint = 0C3F C789 DA17 1BAF 40DD  937C B55B D4DD 57A7 73EA

The new key is:

pub   4096R/0x68953CC861A67E7D 2016-02-13
      Key fingerprint = 12E3 2FE5 0618 0D2E 48E1  D0B2 6895 3CC8 61A6 7E7D

The key is also available from: https://keybase.io/mvance

To fetch the full new key from a public key server using GnuPG, run:

  gpg --keyserver keys.gnupg.net --recv-key 0x68953CC861A67E7D

If you already know my old key, you can verify the new key is
signed by the old one by running:

  gpg --check-sigs 0x68953CC861A67E7D

If you are satisfied you have the correct key, I would appreciate it if you
would sign my key:

  gpg --sign-key 0x68953CC861A67E7D

You can upload your signatures to a public keyserver directly:

  gpg --keyserver keys.gnupg.net --send-key 0x68953CC861A67E7D

Or email me (possibly encrypted) the output from:

  gpg --armor --export 0x68953CC861A67E7D

Please contact me directly if you would like any further verification or have
any questions about the transition.

To verify the integrity of this statement:

  wget -q -O- https://matthewvance.github.io/cross-tech/downloads/key-transition-2016-02-18.txt|gpg --verify

Matt

entry.title: Pi Served: Recommended Parts
entry.summary:
If this is your first Raspberry Pi, you need to make sure you have the right parts before you can really start playing with it. My recommendations for a home Linux server are below, but you can of course use alternatives to your liking/budget (the last two are completely optional accessories).

  • Apple 12W USB Power Adapter - I like the Apple version because it’s rated for 5.2 volts and 2.4 amps which is more than sufficient to support overclocking and any Pi accessories I may decide to add in the future. Also, when it comes to electrical stuff I’d rather by a brand which should have some good quality control and safety measures in place.
  • Samsung Pro Plus 32GB MicroSDHC Memory Card with 95MB/s Read, 90MB/s Write - This card likely supports read/write speeds faster than the Pi is capable of reading/writing, but I got a great deal on at the time and don’t have to worry about the card being a bottleneck. However, at the current price at the time of this post, I suggest you also look at the SanDisk Extreme 16GB microSDHC UHS-1.
  • Inexpensive Ethernet Cable - I had a spare one in my parts bucket and any basic cable should do so I don’t have a specific recommendation. A wireless USB adapter is alternative option, but I prefer wired connections when practical.
  • Micro-USB Cable - As with the Cat5 cable, I had a spare so I don’t have a specific recommendation. If in doubt, the AmazonBasics brand should be a safe choice.
  • Inexpensive Heatsink Set - If you plan to overclock and keep this in an enclosed, fan-less case, a heatsink might help. I received some as a gift and am not sure of which brand I have. Any set with decent reviews online should meet your needs.
  • Premium Clear Case for Raspberry Pi 2 Model B Quad Core and Raspberry Pi Model B+ (B PLUS) - This is a matter of preference. I like the clear style and accessibility to all the ports and pins provided by this case.

If you’re new to the Pi like I was, I hope the above list will be a good starting point for acquiring the accessories needed for a home server project.

entry.title: Pi Served: Raspberry Pi Series Announcement
entry.summary: I received my first Raspberry Pi this past Christmas and have really enjoyed it. While I have not done any neat maker type things with it, I’ve turned it into a LEMP (Linux, NGINX, MariaDB, and PHP) and network/resource monitoring server. As a way to give back to the community, I thought it would be good if I created a series to document the process. Being a security guy, I plan to give some security tips along the way. I plan to post the articles online as I complete them.

entry.title: Obligatory First Post
entry.summary:
Every blog must have a first post so this one is it. I will go ahead and admit this site is very much a work in progress. I’ve been thinking about publishing a personal website for quite a while now and keep hoping to have time to configure everything the way I want before launching the site.

Alas though, I have come to the realization I am better off publishing something now and putting on the finishing touches on the site over the coming months. This will at least give me a platform to begin sharing helpful information with you.

hile I do not like to make excuses, I think it is fair to say I have had other priorities than working on this blog. Indeed, life has been extra crazy this year. To give you an idea of just how crazy life has been for my family:

  • We have moved from Chile to the United States;
  • I started a new job (or rather returned to the employer I worked for prior to moving to Chile in 2012);
  • We purchased a house;
  • We had a baby.

And…all that was within the first four months of this year.
